passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: Eratosthenes says that Syene and Alexandria lie under the same meridian

evidence_items.rationale: Explicit attribution to Eratosthenes with geographical detail

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: Since the distance between Syene and Alexandria is known from the measurements of the royal surveyors—5,000 stadia

evidence_items.rationale: Cleomedes preserves the exact distance figure and attributes it to royal surveyors

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: the sun at the summer solstice casts no shadow in Syene while at Alexandria it makes an angle of one-fiftieth of a circle from the vertical

evidence_items.rationale: Cleomedes provides precise angular measurement method (1/50th circle)

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: the circumference of the Earth must be 252,000 stadia

Ptolemy uses this measurement in his astronomical calculations

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: But some add 2,000 more, making 252,000 stadia

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: The proofs that the Earth is spherical are numerous […] The circular shadow cast during lunar eclipses

evidence_items.rationale: Strabo discusses spherical Earth proofs in context of Eratosthenes' work

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: Some have said the Earth is flat, but the geometrical proofs refute this

evidence_items.rationale: Cleomedes' detailed geometrical arguments suggest polemical context

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: The inhabited world extends from the Pillars of Heracles in the west to the easternmost parts of Asia

evidence_items.rationale: Strabo's geographical work follows Eratosthenes' conception of the oikoumene

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: Having determined the circumference of the Earth to be 252,000 stadia, we may construct a map on a spherical surface

evidence_items.rationale: Strabo describes map-making based on Eratosthenes' measurements
